text: EXTREME CLOSE UP on a single BEAD OF SWEAT. The skin it belongs to is out of focus.

What have you learned from this and how has it prepared you for the future?” The lone bead of sweat begins its slow descent. RACK FOCUS on the bead of sweat to REVEAL the “skin” is actually a beer bottle. And then we SLOWLY PULL BACK to show who the voice and beer belong to: SUTTER KEELY, 18, boyishly handsome, killer smile. He takes a swig of the beer, staring at a college application on his computer. As he thinks about the answer, we get a glimpse of Sutter’s room. A small desk. A twin bed. Clothes on the floor. Decorations include a baseball pennant from some minor league team and a framed photo of the Rat Pack. BACK ON Sutter, staring down the application. An idea comes to him. He starts to type.

“Dear... Dean of Admissions... My name is Sutter Keely and up until yesterday I had the best fucking girlfriend in the world.” INT CASSIDY’S LIVING ROOM - DAY CASSIDY (18, Scandinavian blonde, pure soft skin, hot) takes off her shirt, revealing her voluptuous body. She’s on top of Sutter, who lies on his back on the floor. Sutter looks up at her, can’t believe how lucky he is. INT SUTTER’S BEDROOM - SAME Sutter types.
I know I probably shouldn’t say “fuck” right there but I’m sorry, I have to.  INT CASSIDY’S LIVING ROOM - DAY Naked, Cassidy grinds on Sutter. Getting into it. Her eyes are closed. She’s in control.

She’s tremendous. High definition. And so damn beautifully fat. Like, in a good way. You know what I mean? Immaculate proportions. I dated Cassidy two months longer than anyone else. It was magic. INT SUTTER’S BEDROOM - SAME Sutter stops typing. Takes another drink. Mulls something over.
Shit. I’m getting ahead of myself. Let’s start at the beginning.
Sutter pulls into the parking lot of a suburban strip mall off the highway. There’s a vast openness in every direction. The horizon unsettlingly far away.
Like all great stories, mine begins with a breakfast burrito... Sutter gets out of his car and notices, in front of the store, a YOUNG KID (8), hands in his pockets, kicking a rock.
Hey little man, you ok? (no answer) Shouldn’t you be in school or something? The Kid shrugs. Sutter nods to him as he walks:
Sutter goes to the soft drink counter and pours himself a Big Gulp of 7UP. The Kid follows him inside. As the Clerk rings Sutter up, the Kid sheepishly tugs on his shirt.
Can I borrow a dollar?
What do you need a dollar for?
Three Musketeers.
How bout a tasty breakfast burrito? On me.
And a Three Musketeers?
(laughs; to the Clerk) You heard him.
Sutter and the Kid exit the store. Sutter has his Big Gulp. Kid has his breakfast. Sutter is about to walk away when he realizes -- this Kid isn’t going anywhere.

Granted I was late to pick up Cass for school. But I couldn’t just leave him on the side of the road, could I? INT SUTTER’'S CAR - MOMENTS LATER Sutter drives and Walter sits next to him. Barren branches on the tree-lined streets.
So where to my good man?
Florida.
(surprised) Florida?
I'm going to see my Dad. This effects Sutter, who turns to look at the Kid.
What’s, uh, what’s he doing there?
He was fighting a lot. With my Mom. She made him leave us.
No shit, dude! High five! (off his confused look) Same thing happened to me and my sister!
Really?
Mm-hmm. I was 8 or 9. Just like you. My Dad was the best... Sutter takes a drink from his Big Gulp. His heart breaking for this kid.
You're really going, huh? Walter nods.

Well good for you, kid. I think that’s very brave. (beat) Got any money? (he doesn’t) Cash? Credit cards...? Nothing like that? You know Florida’s pretty far, right? What if you get hungry? (he shrugs) Well you’re gonna need food, aren’t you?
I could hunt it.
Ha. That’s true. You could hunt it. You got a gun? Knife? Fishing rod, at least...?
I have a baseball bat.
That could work! Where’s your bat?
It’s at home.
Hmm. You know what I think? I think maybe we should go get your bat.
But we can’t. My mom is there.
What if I talk to her? Explain the situation.
I don’t know...
Hey, you’re with the Sutterman. (takes a big drink) Don’t you worry bout a thing.
Sutter knocks. WALTER'S MOM (late 20s, pretty) opens it.
Walter!? What are you doing out of school?
Pardon me, ma’am, but, uh, Walter’s sort of upset. The Woman looks at Walter who looks away. At which point she looks at the Big Gulp, then back up at Sutter.
Who are you?
My name’s Sutter Keely. I found him over at the 7/11.
(beat; smells something) Have you been drinking?
Uh, no ma’am. (already backing away) Just thought you might like your kid back, that’s all. I’m gonna go now. And once at his car:

By the way... you are just stunning to look at. The Woman eyes Sutter one last beat, then walks inside, angrily slamming the door behind her. Sutter shakes his head -- the nerve of some people -- gets in his car.

Moms... what can I tell ya? INT SUTTER’S BEDROOM - AGAIN ANGLE ON a_framed picture by his bedside, showing Sutter (5) on the shoulders of a HANDSOME MAN, his father. Back on Sutter, at his desk, as he continues typing:
I enjoy a drink from time to time. For me, it’s like a hobby.
Sutter parks his Mitsubishi Lancer. He takes a swig from a flask before walking into school.
A pleasant diversion from all the annoying responsibilities that come with being a kid.
The class runs laps around the track. We see Sutter in the middle of the pack running backwards, smiling. Kids crack up at his antics.

Gym class. INT SUTTER’'S DINING ROOM - NIGHT Sutter’s family sits at the table. Mom MARY, sister HOLLY, Holly’s husband JOE. The family says “Grace” and with their eyes closed, Sutter seizes the opportunity for a quick drink.
Xmas Dinner with my family. INT SUTTER’S BEDROOM - AGAIN
This essay. Sutter takes another sip. Continues.
Sutter reveals, from beneath his T-shirt, a keg tap. PARTYGOERS cheer and applaud. Sutter is the man.
People talk about the dangers of drinking, how harmful it is Nobody talks about the good stuff. How great it feels. How much fun it can be.

SERIES OF SHOTS: Sutter does shots with friends, including Cassidy. - Sutter standing up on a couch leading the room in a song.  - Sutter diving into a pool fully clothed. Partygoers follow him in. Over which we hear:

When I’m drinking, it’s like I can see another dimension to the world. Words and ideas I never knew I had come flying out of me. I’m funny, compassionate, in love with everything. INT SUTTER’S BEDROOM - AGAIN Sutter typing.

Besides, it’s not like I’m some toothless derelict drinking by himself late at night. I’m 18. This is what I’m supposed to be doing. Sutter takes another swig. Confident now. He continues: EXT CASSIDY’S HOUSE - DAY Sutter knocks on the door. No answer. He can hear loud, angry music blaring from inside.
So meanwhile, thanks to Walter, I’m late to pick my girlfriend up for school. Sutter calls for her. Nothing. Knocks again. Still nothing.

Shit. Sutter walks around back. He sizes up the large tree next to the house. Takes a sip from his cup. QUICK JUMP CUTS of SUTTER: - climbing the tree, Big Gulp in hand - leaping to the roof, Big Gulp in his teeth - lunging for the Big Gulp and losing his grip on the roof - hanging from the gutter when Cassidy appears at the window:
Sutter?!
Hey gorgeous.

What are you -- ? The gutter rips from the side of the house, taking Sutter down with it. He lands hard on his tailbone with a yelp. Cassidy stands over him, arms crossed, livid. INT CASSIDY’S LIVING ROOM - MINUTES LATER Sutter sits on the couch, rubbing his injuries. Cassidy paces as she reprimands Sutter.
Do you even remember what we talked about?

(no idea) Of... course I do. SUTTER’S VOICE I had absolutely no idea what she’s talking about. Cassidy’s lips move as she continues her rant but all we hear is: SUTTER’S VOICE She’s always saying something or other and I try to listen, honest to God, but I mean... look at her.
Cause it’s the last time I’m gonna say it.
I...’m with you. 100 percent.
Promise?

Cross my heart, hope to die. (beat) Now how bout a kiss? Cassidy tries to stay mad at Sutter but it’s virtually impossible. He throws her that smile and her resolve crumbles. They quickly undress and start getting into it. Sutter looks up at her. Can’t believe how lucky he is.
What can I say, I’m a romantic. I am in love with the feminine species. It’s a shame you only get to pick one, but since that’s the rule, I was very grateful for the one I had.
Home of the Plainsmen.
Well the next day, it all went to shit. A bell rings, signaling the end of the day. Kids spill out of the building and head in all directions.
You remember high school. Everyone’s got their thing. ANGLE ON a tough-looking jock with a varsity jacket.
Denver Quigley, his thing is sports. ANGLE ON a long-haired kid in a back Jim Morrison shirt.

Josh Green. Biggest Doors fan in the state. ANGLE ON Sutter, who stands by the entrance with his best friend RICKY (18, undersized, Indian-American). Sutter points to a girl. Ricky shakes his head no.
My best friend Ricky... he’s Indian. Sutter points to another. Again, Ricky rejects.
And me, my thing is making people feel good. I’m the fun guy. Just like my dad. There’s no feeling down when ol’ Sutter's around.
Colleen Marshall?
Way too tall. I’d look like her son.
That’s it. I’m tired of your excuses. I say, “tonight’s the night.”
What night?

The night I get you some action.  10. INT/EXT SUTTER’S CAR - DOWNTOWN STREET - NIGHT Cars zoom by as Sutter and Ricky drive extra slow with the windows down, scoping left and right for something or someone to perk up the evening. It may be “Downtown” but there’s little to do. Ricky pulls out a blaze and lights it. Sutter sips from his Big Gulp.
I don’t know about this.
Relax. From behind the car, headlights flash. Sutter squints through the rearview. See two girls waving excitedly. Sutter smiles. RICKY (CONT’D) What is it?
Potential. Sutter pulls into a shopping plaza. The girls’ car pulls up alongside him. The driver is BETHANY, the passenger TARA.
Hi Tara. Bethany.
Just the man I was looking for. Know where we can score some beers?

(does he ever) Step into my office ladies. Sutter gets out and gestures to the back of his car. He pops the trunk, revealing that he’s turned the trunk into a cooler -- it’s filled to the brim with ice and beer.
My hero.
Bethany, you know Ricky don’t you? Ricky awkwardly waves. Bethany awkwardly waves back.
So what’s your plan for tonight?
(laughs) Plans? You know me better than that. I don’t plan, I improvise.  11. Sutter looks around.
You guys up for a boat ride? Off their faces we...
A canal runs between two long rows of buildings like a river at the bottom of a canyon. Sutter helps Ricky and Bethany get on the boat.
It takes me all of 30 seconds to get them alone.
Oh shit. I left my wallet in the car.
I have enough --
(hinting) No dude, don’t worry about it. You guys go ahead. I’1l run back and get it. (to Tara) You’1ll come with me, right?
Sure. As the boat floats away Sutter winks at Ricky, who’s now “trapped” on the boat with Bethany.
(calling after them) See you guys in a bit. Ricky looks at Bethany and can only shrug. Back on land:
Want some ice cream?
I thought you lost your wallet.
(pulls it out of his pocket) Hey, whaddaya know?
You're terrible.  12.
They make a cute couple, don’t they? INT SUTTER’S CAR - LATER Sutter and Tara are drinking. A baseball game plays on the radio.
I can’t wait to get out of this place. Can we put on some music or something?
No I like this. Tara thinks this strange but doesn’t say so. It’s at this point when a car comes careening into the parking lot. Sutter and Tara turn. Cassidy storms out of the car. Furious.
(upbeat) Hey Cass --
Can I speak to you in private please? Sutter goes to give Cass a hug but she pushes him off.
Kendra said she saw you with Tara. I didn’t believe her.
Uh, yeah, the girls wanted some beers so--
I asked you to do one thing for me. One. And you still couldn’t do it.
What are you so mad about? What thing?
I asked you to put someone else’s feelings before your own. For once in your life!
Wait a sec. That is what I’m doing!
Oh please --
It’s the truth! Ask Ricky. I’m just here to --  13.
You're the most selfish person I’ve ever met.
Are you hearing me? I’m doing this for Ricky. I’m completely unselfish. Cassidy sees Tara in the car, beer in hand. Tara looks away, like she knows she was doing something wrong.
You’re a lost cause, Sutter.
Cass, you gotta believe me --
I’m sorry. No. We’re done.
Cassidy! It’s too late. She gets in the car and drives off. Sutter stands there. Buzzed enough to not be upset. Yet.
We're back with Sutter. He looks up from the page. Thinks for a moment, and then continues writing:

A misunderstanding. No big deal. She’d come around, right? Well listen to this. Fucking last night... INT SUTTER’S CAR - AGAIN Sutter drives crosstown, the sound of a baseball announcer again fills the car. He nips from the flask.

A nicer neighborhood. There’s nowhere for Sutter to park so he decides, fuck it, he’s double parking. Sutter gets out and walks towards the biggest house on the block. There’s a party going on inside. En route to the front door, he plucks a handful of flowers from a neighbor's garden.

Flowers in hand, Sutter wanders through the place looking for Cassidy. The house is huge and expensively decorated. Occasional partygoers high-five him on the way but he’s in no mood to be social right now. And then he sees her. Sitting on the couch, playing with the hair of MARCUS WEST (18, tall, lanky, athletic).  14.
Well this is unexpected. Cass and Marcus turn. Cassidy is surprised to see him.
What are you doing here? Knowing he’s lost her, Sutter hides the flowers behind his back.
You got a haircut.
Yeah I... seemed like a good time for a change.
Goddamn stunning, that haircut.
Are you drunk or something?
Well if drunk equals A, and something equals B, let’s just say the answer is... definitely not B. Marcus looks at Sutter with a touch of sympathy.
Look man, I know this is awkward. Maybe we should talk outside--
Marcus West! Speaking to me?! What an honor!
Oh God, Sutter...
Come on man, let’s go out to my car.

Thank you excellency, but that won’t be necessary. I am a fair-minded individual who thoroughly understands the meaning of the phrase ‘kicked to the curb.’ Sutter bows, struggling to keep his balance. Then backs away.
Sutter...  15.
I bid you both a pleasant evening. Marcus wants to stop Sutter from leaving but Cassidy puts her arm out.
Let him go. He drives better that way.

(still backing away) Thanks for the vote of confidence, beautiful! You are the most understanding woman... in everything but love. Arrivederci! Sutter turns with a flourish and stumbles away. INT SUTTER’S BEDROOM - AGAIN Sutter finishes the essay in a flurry.
Unbelievable, isn’t it? You want hardship, misfortune, well there you go.
- Sutter getting dressed for the evening. - Sutter drinking some more.

A weaker-minded individual would get depressed. Sit in his room, maybe cry about it. Not this guy. Not Sutter Keely. Don’t count me out just yet, Dean of Admissions. It’s another day, and the night is just getting started. So forget Cassidy, forget exams, forget these pointless college apps. Fuck the past, fuck the future. all that matters is the here and now.
- Sutter looking at himself in the mirror, psyching himself up for the night ahead.

I’m Sutter Keely and I say... it’s time to be alive. And with that, on Sutter smiling: Music up: The Walkmen/ “The Rat”  16. INT SUTTER’S CAR - NIGHT Music continues over Sutter driving, two hands on the wheel. Drumming a bit to the loud music. Psyching himself up for a good night. (Note: when Sutter is drinking, his
world is vibrant, sharp, rich in color. It won’t always be this way.

- Sutter gets turned away by a BOUNCER. Pretends it doesn’t bother him. - Sutter ambles along down the promenade. Takes a nip at his flask. All around him, YOUNG COUPLES stroll past. He tips his imaginary hat at a BUSKER playing acoustic guitar on the street. - Sutter turned away from another bar. Now getting frustrated. Sees a sign for a bar across the way and the best part -- no bouncer.
In comes Sutter. The place is crowded. As luck would have it, he spots a table full of COLLEGE GIRLS. Decides to approach.

Ladies... I’m 18 years old and I just got dumped by my girlfriend. Will someone, anyone, please have a drink with me? A beat. The Girls are delighted to meet him! - Sutter and the Girls do a round of shots. Then another. They love this kid. - Sutter dances between two of the Girls. They play with his hair, pinch his cheeks. Innocent fun.
Sutter and the Girls are leaving. We quickly realize they’re not leaving together. As they walk away Sutter yells after them.
I love you! The Girls look back and laugh -- he’s so cute.
I love everyone! But the Girls keep walking.  17. INT SUTTER’S CAR - LATER Cruising - windows down, wind in his face, radio on. Drunk and feeling much better now.
(yelling out the window) You are holy! You are beautiful! Down with the king! Down with the motherfucking-- SMASHCUT TO BLACK.

Um... hello... A face. Or, at least, a head. Female. Completely in shadow from the bright morning sun and thus impossible to make out. Sutter, who has clearly spent the night passed out on the ground, looks up, disoriented. Puts his hand up to see who it is. And we see her. Sutter’s age but looking younger. Pale with freckles and glasses. Her hair is strawberry blonde and her eyes the color of a public swimming pool. Her name is AIMEE FINECKY.
You're alive. When she talks it’s like she just discovered her voice.
I thought maybe you were dead. Sutter blinks a few times.
I don’t think I’m dead... Where the hell am I?
You're in the middle of a yard. Do you know who lives here? Sutter sits up. Looks at the ugly pink little house.
Jesus, I must have gone to sleep. Hey, where’s my car?  18.
Is it one of those? Sutter looks at the nearby parked cars. Can’t find his anywhere.
Maybe I parked it at home and just went for a walk.
You don’t live in this neighborhood. Do you, Sutter?
You know my name?
We go to the same school... You wouldn’t remember me.
No... of course I do. You’re um...
Aimee. Aimee Finecky.
Right. Aimee. I was about to say that. (standing) What time is it, Aimee?
6am.
Are you coming back from a party or something?
I’m on my paper route. She motions to the white pickup truck that’s pulled over. We see the back is filled with papers.
It’s really my mom’s paper route but she went to the casino last night with my step-dad. She hasn’t come back yet.
You need some help?
I can manage.
No I’ll help you.  19.
You don’t have to --

Aimee, you’re driving round the neighborhood, I gotta find my car. I’m thinking we can help each other out. Whaddaya say? Off her look: INT AIMEE’S CAR - LATER Aimee drives and Sutter throws papers while looking for his car. It takes a few throws until Sutter gets the hang of it.
I didn’t realize newspaper throwing was such big business. You must reel in some cash.
My mom does.
What, and you get nothing?!
I get an allowance.
An allowance? That doesn’t sound fair. I mean, You do all the work.
Well yeah but... she pays the bills... most of them.

Most of them?! Aimee, she’s your mom! (off her shrug) Aw man, I don’t know. Sounds to me like a pretty raw deal, this paper route. If I were you, I’d say something. A sad smile comes over her face. Standing up for herself is the last thing Aimee ever does. Sutter feels bad for her, decides to change the subject. Throwing more papers:
I’m getting the hang of this, aren’t I?
You're a natural.  20.
Back in Little League, You should have seen me. I had this booming arm. Here. Watch this. (throws right on target) Look at that! Are you impressed?
Very.
I had the gift, Aimee. That’s what my Dad used to say. Probably could have gone pro if I stuck with it.
So what happened?
Hmm?
Why didn’t you stick with it? Sutter doesn’t answer.
Hey look! There it is! Sutter’s Mitsubishi is parked sideways in the middle of a lawn. Aimee pulls over.
What’s it doing on the lawn?
That is a very good question. Aimee assumes that now the car has been spotted Sutter will take off.
Well... thanks again. For helping me.
(motioning to all the papers) Whaddaya mean? We’re not done yet!
You don’t have to --
Hey it’s the least I can do. Besides, I’m enjoying myself. Let’s keep going. The light flips back on in her eyes.  21.
(beat) Should you move your car first?
Yes. Good idea. Sutter jumps out to move his car. Aimee waits. Smiles. INT AIMEE’S CAR - LATER Now they're having fun delivering the papers.
Fire the torpedo, Special Agent Danger!
Aye aye, Captain! Sutter launches another paper. It lands right on the doorstep.
(explosion sound effect) Direct shot! They share a laugh. It’s nice. - LATER. Paper route over.
We make a good team, don’t we?
You think so?
Absolutely. Sutter catches the look on Aimee’s face. She’s beaming.
You know what, Aimee Finecky? I had a pretty rotten night last night until you came along. We should get lunch sometime.
How bout Monday?
Oh...k Monday it is. Where should we meet?
The cafeteria?  22.
Why not! We can relive our greatest triumphs of newspaper delivery! Aimee smiles at him. It’s nerdy but endearing.

See you Monday, Captain. With that, he’s off. Feeling pretty good about it too. INT SUTTER’S HOME - LATER It’s a modest house, the bottom rung of middle class. In the kitchen Sutter finds his mother, MARY (40s, faded beauty) already up and dressed in her work clothes. She moves in and out of the room as she readies for the long day, barely looking at her son.
You're up early.
I uh...
(not listening) They have me on a double shift... again. Sutter heads up to his room.
(suddenly) Dammit Sutter. Sutter stops in his tracks. Uh-oh. Mary comes out of the utility room holding her uniform jacket.
Didn’t I asked you to hang this for me? Look how wrinkled this is? That’s what she’s mad about?
I’m sorry. I forgot.
It would have taken you two seconds to hang this up and help me. Is that too much to ask?
I’m sorry, I just --
It's not like I ask you to do so much around here. Christ. (MORE )
(shakes head; almost to herself) Sometimes you act just like your father. Sutter’s face suggests that’s alright with him. Like a tornado, Mary passes through one last time.
I may not be back in time for dinner. There’s leftovers in the fridge. Or if you want, call your sister --
(hates that idea) No thanks.
K, well, I’ve got to go. Sutter starts to walk off.
Sutter. Sutter turns back around.
Next time I ask you do to something... Mary doesn’t finish. She just shakes her head. And with that she’s out the door.

(to no one) I love you too. INT SUTTER’S BEDROOM - LATER Sutter lays in his bed, looking up at the baseball pennant. Thinking. Miles Davis plays softly in the background. His alarm goes off but of course he doesn’t need it. He hasn’t slept. INT RICKY’S CAR - MORNING Ricky drives Sutter to school. Sutter has his flask and is back to his completely relaxed self.
..-who knew dinner and a movie would cost more than 30 bucks?
Pretty much anyone who’s ever been on a date.  24.
Oh but the best part is... she didn’t care, dude! She paid for the popcorn and everything. She’s just... mmm.
You kiss her?
Check.
Tongue action?
Double check. The boys high five. Sutter looks at Ricky and smiles. Likes seeing him happy. Knows he had a hand in it.
Wanna go to the Barons game tonight?
Hell yeah.
It's father/son night. We’ll pretend to be brothers. Hearing this, a look comes over Sutter’s face.
Oh I, uh, actually... shit. I forgot. There’s a... I promised my mom I'd help her with something.
You sure? Sutter nods. Ricky turns back to the road. Sutter looks out the window.
So, uh, where to for lunch today?
I thought you were eating with what’s her name.
Oh shit. That’s right.
I gotta tell ya Sutter. Aimee Finecky? Strange choice for a rebound.  25.
She’s not a rebound. (off his look) She’s not! (another look) I have no interest in dating Aimee Finecky.
Then what’s the point of lunch?

I think she’s nice, is all. Maybe too nice. Did I tell you bout her paper route? Listen to this. Her mom has her throwing newspapers at 5am, 6 days a week, schooldays and all. She keeps all the money, pays half the bills, and Aimee never says a word about it!
That sucks.
It’s bullshit’s what it is.
So where do you come in?
I can help her.
Oh, here we go. Sutter to the rescue.
She just needs a little confidence is all. Who better than me to bring it out of her?
Uh-huh. So... you don’t want to nail her?
Dude, what is wrong with you?
MR. ASTER (50s, beard) solves a geometry problem on the chalkboard. The bell rings and students begin to leave.
Sutter, can I have a word?
Uh... actually I have to--  26.
Have a seat, Mr. Keely. Sutter really doesn’t want to have a seat but there’s not much he can do about it.
Noticed you didn’t turn in the homework.
(suddenly animated) And I have a really good reason why, Mr. Aster. You’re not even gonna believe it when I --
Stop talking.
Yes sir.
Sutter, as your teacher, I only want to see you succeed. You know that, don’t you?
Sure I do.
And if you fail... that means I fail.
I know, Mr. Aster. And believe me, I will get it together. From here on in.
I wanna believe you.
(standing) Well you should. I’m turning a corner, I promise --
Let’s see you answer this.
Sorry?
(handing him a sheet) If one of the acute angles is 2 times as large as the other, what’s the measure of the two angles? (no idea) Siddown, I’1ll show you.  27. Sutter is a deer in headlights.
Sutter emerges from Aster’s class, super late to meet Aimee. He races through the hallway on his way to:
Sutter enters, looking all around for her. Just as he thinks he’s missed her, there she is. Standing alone by the lunch line. Waiting.
I’m so sorry --
You came!
Well of course I did. Why wouldn’t I? Sutter takes in the scene (only the lamest of the lame eat in the lunchroom).
You actually eat here?
Isn’t that what it’s for?
Well yeah but nobody ever... I mean, I’ve never... (not wanting to insult) What’s good, I’m starving? He gets up to go to the lunch line, gesturing for her to come with.
The tater tots are pretty solid. - LATER. Sutter and Aimee at the table.
That’s so crazy! How fast were you going?
20, 25 miles per hour.
And you just jumped out of the car? Aimee is hanging on every word.  28.
There was snow on the ground. I didn’t think it would hurt.
That’s amazing.
Look at you, you’re such a great listener. Ok, now you go.
Um... well, I remember... sophomore year. When you wore that mascot head to gym class and wouldn’t take it off...
Oh yeah.
That was so funny.
Yeah, no, I mean, stories about you.
I don’t have any stories.
Of course you do. Everyone does.
Not me.
Come on. What’s your thing?
My thing?
Yeah, like... what do you love? What do you want to be known for? Larry Rourke’s the stoner. Greg Jacoby’s the rich kid. We all have a thing.
(beat; thinks) I'd like to think there’s more to people than just one thing. You know? Sutter smiles, impressed.
Is that ok? At which point, a supremely uncool girl approaches. This is KRYSTAL.  29.
So he finally got here, did he?
Hi Krystal.
(standing like a gentleman) Krystal, hey, Sutter Keely.
I know who you are. Come on Aimee. French Club. They’re waiting for us. Aimee clearly wants to stay but standing up to people isn’t her thing.
I forgot about the meeting. I’m sorry.
No worries. As she’s walking away:
Hey Aimee, you ever have Aster for geometry?
Freshmen year.
Probably thought it was easy, huh?
Kind of.
Could you tutor me? I never know what that guy’s talking about.
Uh, sure, anytime. Aimee writes down her number and hands it to him.

Terrific, thanks. I’1ll call you. Aimee nods, gets up to go, unable to hold back a smile. Krystal gives Sutter one last angry look before walking away. Sutter watches them go. Eats another tater tot. INT LEWIS FINE MEN’S CLOTHING STORE - DAY The store has seen better days. Sutter finishes up a sale to a customer.  30.

You're very welcome. It’s gonna look great on you. Customer leaves passing the owner, BOB LEWIS (late 30s, kind face) saying goodbye to his WIFE and BABY at the door. Sutter watches them go. Once they’re gone:
Will you please just adopt me already?
Sorry bud, two’s my limit on mouths to feed. So where were we...
Cassidy.
Oh right. That’s a shame. I really liked that one. When Bob is turned around, Sutter pours some whiskey into his soda can. Careful not to let Bob see this.
So did I.
I kinda thought she’d be the one to yank you out of neutral.

Neutral? What neutral? I’m in overdrive. (off his look) What? EXT/INT AIMEE’S HOUSE - AFTERNOON A small brick cube surrounded by a bare yard. Some shingles are missing from the roof and the original paint color has faded away. Sutter knocks.

Aimee, your boyfriend’s here. AIMEE’S VOICE (V.O.) Shut up Shane. Please. The door opens. Aimee has put some effort into her looks this afternoon. Most notably, she’s wearing lipstick. He'd never say so but Sutter would rather she wasn’t.
Hey there.  31.

Come in. Sutter follows Aimee inside. We take in the total mess that is Aimee’s living situation. Clothes piled up on the recliner, opened containers covering the tiny coffee table, VHS tapes scattered on the floor. Aimee’s little brother SHANE (11) plays an ancient video game system wearing shorts and no shirt.
This is Shane, my brother.
Hello Shane. Shane flips Sutter the two-handed bird.
He just learned that.
Charming.
We can study in my room.

Lead the way. Sutter follows Aimee down the narrow hallway. Notices more mess, some tacky wall hangings. Sutter catches a glimpse of Aimee’s step-dad RANDY, taking a nap in one room (dressed exactly like Shane). Finally they get to Aimee’s bedroom. Sutter is expecting the worst but when she opens the door, it’s an awesomely neat and colorful place, clearly a sanctuary from the world outside. Sutter is impressed.
Wow, nice.

I like to keep it clean. Sutter walks around the room, admiring. The back wall is a giant map of the Milky Way. There’s some pencil drawings and ceramic cats scattered about. On one wall is a massive bookshelf covered in notebooks and paperbacks. Welcome to Aimee’s World.
You must really love reading.
They're mostly science fiction. A few mysteries.  32. Sutter picks up one book that’s half in Japanese. “Battle of the Immortal.”
(apologetically) I know it’s weird.
No that’s cool. Weird is good. I say “embrace the weird.” Why’s it backwards?
That’s how you read them. See? She shows Sutter how it works. He’s impressed. Notices on the wall one of the pencil drawings -- an anime-style scene of a woman flying through space.
Is this you flying through space?
No, it’s, um... it’s nothing. Just this thing I like.
Who is she? Aimee is embarrassed... but Sutter silently encourages her to answer.
She’s... Shirei Migoto. From the Bright Planet books. Stupid, I know.
If you like it, it’s not stupid. What makes her so special?
She’s the leader of the Neexo Ark. It’s up to her to escape the Dark Galaxy and find the Bright Planet star system.
(looking at another drawing) I... see... There’s drawings of the Commander everywhere.
(still shyly) She’s kind of my hero... and stuff. Sutter feels exceedingly bad for this girl right now.  33.
You know what? You’ll be my hero if you can straighten me out on this geometry business.
Sure. They sit down and get situated. Sutter opens the big textbook.
So... quadrilaterals. Talk to me.
How much of this have you read? Sutter looks up. Smiles. He hasn’t read a word of course. - LATER. They’ve been at it a while.
So, in this figure, angle 2 and angle 4 are... (Sutter has no clue) Complementary angles.
Complementary. Got it. Man, you’re a wonderful teacher, Miss Finecky.
So then, you understand?
Well... here’s what I don’t understand. When on earth will I ever need to know this stuff?
Um...
I mean, seriously. Vectors? Slopes? Coplanar lines? Who gives a shit? Who calculates slopes at their job? Aimee laughs. And then:
Aimee! Come out here right now, will you! The craggy voice belongs to Randy. Hearing it saps the fun vibe of the room almost immediately.
My step-dad.  34.
That’s ok.
We're all out of milk, Aimee. I thought you were going to get some.
I will!
Do it now, crissakes. The hell has she been doing all afternoon? It’s quiet for a beat.
I should really... Aimee smiles her sad smile, starts putting on her shoes.
Yeah, sure. No problem. The expression on her face is like her ship just crashed back to Earth. Sutter feels terrible.
You know what, there’s this party on Saturday. I think you should go with me.
Me?
Yeah you. I’1ll come by and grab you around 8:30. What do you say?
Um... ok?
Is that an answer or a question?
No, I mean, yeah, yes. I'd like that.

Sutter comes out of the convenience store with his Big Gulp. On the way to his car, he passes a comic book store. Sutter walks right by before stopping and turning around. INT SUTTER’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Sutter finishes mixing a drink, turns on Thelonious Monk’s “Straight, No Chaser”, and sits down at his desk.  35. We see a stack of Manga books which Sutter bought at the store. He puts his feet up and begins to read through one in reverse. INSERT: elegantly drawn images from the books, the occasional caption about dreams, freedom, the future. Sutter finds himself surprisingly captivated. We hear the chime of an Instant Message. Sutter looks up from the book to his computer. He’s got a message from “CASSIDY210." (Her icon is a seductive personal pic). The message just says “Hey.” Sutter perks up. This is a nice, new development. He writes back... Sutter&7: “Hey.” (His icon: Sinatra). Takes a swig. Her message: “How are you?” Sutter drinks some more. Writes back: “Fabuloso.” Then it’s quiet for a few beats. Sutter scratches his head, thinking of the right thing to say. But then he gets this: “I_miss you.” Sutter’s eyes open wide. Writes back: “Will I see you tomorrow?” And then “Rlisa’s party.” Her message: “Think so.” Then, as Sutter is writing back, she sends: “Gotta _go. Talk soon.” And signs off. Sutter returns his attention to the Manga but his mind is now very much elsewhere.

head_text.subj: EXT LAKE SIDE HIGH SCHOOL PARTY

text: A bonfire. Picnic tables. Kegs. Music. Twenty or so high school kids already in the swing of things. Sutter and Aimee approach the party. Aimee wears an oversized purple winter coat that makes her look rotund. Sutter badly wants her to take it off.
You sure you don’t want me to carry your coat?
It’s kinda chilly out. Oh well, he tried. As they walk towards the keg, pretty much everyone they pass says “Hi” to Sutter or slaps him five. He’s the king of these high school parties.
See anyone you know?
I don’t really know a lot of people.
Well that, my dear, is about to change.  36. At the keg, Sutter is saluted by some classmates.
How bout a brew?
Um, I don’t... really...
Don’t drink it, just hold it. Gives off the illusion you’re having fun.
Now it’s a party! This is JASON DOYLE (collar up, smarmy as hell). Sutter has no love for this dude.
Whattup Sutterman? You gonna dive in the lake again tonight?
We'll see.
You're crazy dude. (eyeing Aimee) And who might I ask is this?
Aimee. Jason and Aimee shake hands. Jason is either going to hit on her or poke fun at her. Sutter doesn’t care to find out which.
Doyle, what are you doing talking to us? Shouldn’t you be going for Alisa Norman now that she’s single?
Alisa Norman? Since when?
Couple days.
You shitting me?
I am shitting you not. Jason, intrigued, hurries off to find Alisa.  37.
(to Aimee) I am shitting him big time.
(realizes) You're gonna get that guy killed!
Yeah I feel real bad about it. Aimee laughs. Takes a sip of her drink. Winces. But she takes another sip nonetheless.
You get used to it. Meanwhile, Sutter’s eyes land on a small, preppy kid with a baseball cap. He stands by a picnic table alone with his hands in his pockets.
Come with me. Sutter walks Aimee over to the kid, CODY DENNIS.
Cody, my man.
Hey Sutter.
You guys know each other? This is Aimee. They exchange sheepish “hellos.”
Cody's a sophomore but he’s in all my classes. Aimee here’s a genius too. That doesn’t get them talking very much either. Hmm...
You're a reader, aren’t you Cody? You ever read the Bright Planet books?
(cautiously) One or two.
(to Aimee) I forgot to tell you. I started the first one last night.
You did?  38.
It's really cool. I like the part where Shirei Migoto takes on the Galactic Warlord. She fucks that guy up!
I know, right?!
And all that stuff about “inner prosperity.” Happiness from within. That’s my shit.
You should read the second one. It’s so awesome.
I love those books.
(of course he does) Do you? As Cody tries to get back into the convo, Sutter sees Cassidy appear. Her beauty makes him wince. Meanwhile:
Have you read “Solar Bull?”
Oh my god, I love Solar Bull!
Haven't read that one yet. Cody and Aimee start enthusiastically chatting about it.

You know what. You guys discuss. I’ll be back in like, two seconds. Ok? Aimee and Cody don’t mind. Sutter starts to walk towards Cassidy. On the way, however, he turns back to make sure Aimee is ok. Seeing she’s fine, Sutter makes his way over to Cassidy. She waves. He waves back -- only to discover it wasn’t him she was waving to. It was Marcus. They hug tightly. This stings. Sutter quickly ducks in the direction of the keg. TWO CLASSMATES are playing Beirut.
... I was so pumped when I got in.
Yeah no shit.  39.
I can’t wait to get out of here.
Fucking five more months. (sees Sutter) Hey Sutter.
What’s up guys? Sutter refills his cup, keeping one eye on Cass and Marcus.
Mike’s here if you wanna surf on his car again.
Maybe later. Sutter downs one drink, pours two more, carries them over to Cassidy.
Hello gang.
Sutter.
(to Cass) Who could use a drink?
(as expected) Sure. Sutter notices that the crew around Cass and Marcus seem to be waiting for some kind of incident. Well he’s not going to give them one.
Everyone’s so serious tonight. (beat) How bout a joke? What do you call a fish with no eye? They all wait for it.
A fsshh. It takes a second but eventually Cass starts to laugh. The others join in.  40.

Heard that from an 8 year old running away from home. Want another? Where would you find a dog with no legs...? Right where you left him. Even Marcus finds this one funny. Denver, the athlete, approaches.
What are you guys laughing at?
Sutter.
I should have guessed.
I know. I’m hilarious.
Anyone see Alisa?
Did you two break up or something?
No. Why’d you say that?
Sorry. I thought I saw her with Jason Doyle.
What the fuck --! Denver turns to go find Jason and kick his ass.
Denver, slow down! But he’s off. Jason Doyle is in trouble.
(to Cass) I'll be right back. The other guys go with them, leaving Cass and Sutter alone. Sutter has a canary eating smile on his face.
What did you do?
(winks) Me? Nothing.  41. LATER. Sutter and Cassidy are catching up by the keg.
So Ricky and Beth are officially together?
I wonder how that happened.
You really weren’t going for Tara that night?

Are you nuts? (holds hands out like scales) Over here I have cute little Tara. Nice girl. Good skin. Attractive. But over here, I have spanktaculiciously perfect you. Who do you think I would choose? Cassidy blushes, causing Sutter to smile.
Don’t give me that smile.
I'm sorry. I can’t help myself. At which point a shout rises up on the other side of the crowd. Catcalls of “Fight! Fight!” are audible.

Guess they found Doyle. Sutter and Cass move to get a closer look. Denver is on top of someone, pushing him into the ground. Marcus is trying to hold him back. Cass runs to Marcus’s aid, leaving Sutter alone. But when Sutter is able to see the kid being beaten, it isn’t Jason at all. That’s weird. Confused, he looks around for Jason and finally sees him away from the crowd, standing against a tree -- talking with Aimee.
Fuck. Sutter makes haste over to Aimee, noticing that she looks ready to hurl at any moment.
What’s going on here? Where’s Cody?
Couldn’t handle the competition.  42.
(to Aimee) You all right?
Um, yeah, I’m just, you know, not used to drinking.
Let’s go for a walk. Sutter grabs Aimee and helps her up.
Hey, man, what the --

Get lost douchebag. Sutter takes Aimee by the arm and walks her in another direction. As he does, he catches Cassidy watching him with Aimee. LATER. They walk on a dirt road, far away from the rest of the revelers.
You sure you’re alright?
Thank you. I’m a little... you know.
You like it?
It’s good. It’s... different.
Hey, I’m sorry about Doyle. He’s a dick. I hope he didn’t --
No, we were just... we were just talking.
Wow. You're hammered, aren’t you? Aimee leans up against Sutter. Their shoulders touching. She looks at him and smiles. Sutter isn’t sure what to do so he takes a nip from the flask.
Can I try that?
This? No. This is some serious stuff.  43.
Just a taste. Sutter hesitates but then hands it to her. She takes more than a sip and is immediately coughing and choking. He smiles
How can you drink this?
I’ve been at it a while. You know who gave me my first beer?
Who?
My father. I was probably... 6. We used to go to baseball games every Saturday and he would let me take little sips.
Did you get drunk?
Nah. But it sure felt nice and warm... at this memory.
Where is he now... your father?
He’s an airline pilot. Flies all over the country.
That’s so cool!
He’s a cool guy. The best. I don’t know what he was doing with my mom that whole time.
They’re divorced?
Oh yeah. She threw him out of the house a long time ago. (beat) But it’s fine. Believe me, he’s way better off now. Aimee takes another sip. Winces but doesn’t choke.
Sounds like we have the same mother.
How’s that?
Well for example... I got into college today and there’s no way my mom will let me go.
(beat) You got into college today?
Uh-huh.
No shit!
In St. Louis. Where my sister lives.
That's, I don’t know what to say, Aim. Congratulations!
It doesn’t matter, though... cause my mom
Hold on. What’s your mom have to do with it?
She needs me. There’s no one else to help with the route.
(disbelief) Aimee, seriously. Your mom will be fine. She’s a grown woman. You have to go to St. Louis.
Yeah but --
No. No buts. Don’t you see? You’re like this extraordinary genius chick but you've got all these people making you do stuff. It’s gotta stop.
How?
It’s your life! Stand up for yourself.
It’s not that easy.
I'll teach you. Here... have another swig. Aimee takes the flask. Drinks another sip.
Now repeat after me. “Mom, get off my motherfucking back!”
What?!
Say it.
No! (beat; quietly) Get off my back.
Dude, you've got to say it like you mean it. And the motherfuck is key. Trust me. “Mom...”
“Get off my MOTHERFUCKING back, Mom!”
(beat) “Get off my... fucking... back, Mom!”
Motherfucking.
Motherfucking back! Motherfucker! Aaaah!
Yes!
That sorta feels good.
I told you.
Get off my motherfucking back, mom. Stay out of my motherfucking business, Krystal. 45.  46.
Oh! Krystal got one. Who else?
I think that’s it.
How bout an ex-boyfriend? Fuck you ex- boyfriend! Aimee clamps up. Sutter notices.
Come on. You can’t be 17 and not have one horrible ex-boyfriend you want to curse out. (she doesn’t) Nobody?
It’s not... guys don’t really look at me... like that. You know?
You're crazy. Didn’t you see Jason Doyle hitting on you? And Cody Dennis?
They weren’t hitting on me.
Of course they were. You’re a sweetheart. I mean, look at you. Aimee is not at all convinced. To convince her, Sutter takes hold of her chin, tilts it up, and plants a kiss on her. When it’s over:
Whew.

You’re damn right “whew.” Sutter smiles. Aimee smiles back. So Sutter goes in for another one. Why the hell not? And as they kiss, CUT TO: INT SUTTER’S BEDROOM - THE NEXT DAY Sutter’s asleep in his clothes from the night before. Food wrappers and a stray beer can are littered around the bed. The clock reads: 12:06pm. Sutter stirs. Moans. The hangover is upon him.  47.

Sutter showers. He leans against the wall, head in his arms as the water falls on him. He tries to remember the night before. - FLASH: Sutter and Aimee walk away from the party. Cassidy watching. BACK TO Sutter in the shower. Remembering. - FLASH: Sutter kissing Aimee, like we saw. BACK TO Sutter in the shower. Ok, yeah, that happened. - FLASH: Sutter helping Aimee to get to her front door.

Of course you’re going to the prom. I’1l take you. BACK TO Sutter in the shower. Can’t believe he said that. Rolls back his head in disgust. INT RICKY’S HOUSE - LATER Sutter and Ricky watch a baseball game on TV. Sutter fixes himself a drink.
You made plans with her? Like, future plans?
It’s no big deal.
It’s you making plans. You never make plans.
Relax, will you? I’m just trying to help the girl.
Right I forgot. Sutter to the rescue.
Exactly.

And if she falls for you, what happens then? Sutter dismisses this as nonsense. Ricky holds his gaze.  48. INT SUTTER’S HOUSE - LATER Sutter comes in. Walks into the kitchen. Puts down his stuff. There’s a message on the answering machine. He presses play and hears: AIMEE’S VOICE Sutter, hi, it’s, um, it’s Aimee. Wasn’t sure if we were studying tonight. Call me. If you want. Sutter barely reacts to the message. As he listens, he goes to the fridge. Reads a note from Mom, something about working late and chicken in the microwave. Sutter doesn’t react to that either. Whistling, he bypasses the food and goes straight to the liquor cabinet. INT SUTTER’S BEDROOM - LATER Sutter sits in front of his computer, stirring a drink. He looks at the application essay he has written ("Describe a hardship...”) Sutter highlights the essay (from our opening) and deletes the whole thing. He takes a deep breath. Is about to start over when he hears a sound. ON SCREEN we see “CASSIDY210 is now online”. Sutter opens the chat window. We see “Sutter&7” send her a message: “Hey, beautiful.” Sutter waits for a response. Gets one: Hello you...” Sutter thinks about what to say next. Writes: “What are you doing? Let’s hang out.” Sutter debates sending that. One beat. Two beats. Wills himself to hit send.
No response. Now he’s nervous. Then it comes: “I’m heading out to the mall.” Sutter sits back in his chair. About to give up. And then he receives: “Wanna come?”
They pass Sutter’s flask back and forth as they walk, reminiscing.
.«.-and the time under the bleachers. Who could ever forget that?
Remember the lightning storm?
On your roof! That was amazing!
You’re telling me.  49.
(beat; reflective) I don’t know how many times I’ve ever felt like that.
Not a lot.
But every time was with you.
I think I feel it right now. Cassidy smiles and walks on.
Stop it.

It’s true. When we’re together, it’s like, we’re invincible. Like nothing can touch us, like everything else in the world - the problems, the responsibilities - they all just disappear. Sutter looks right in her eyes. Cassidy looks down.
I don’t want to lose you Sutter. Sutter tenderly touches her cheek.

Then you won't. She looks back up at him. Deciding. INT CASSIDY’S BEDROOM - LATER And now they’re making out on Cassidy’s bed. Clothes are coming off. Every time Sutter tries to say something, she bites his lip.
God you're beautiful.
Don’t talk. Cassidy lies down. They continue kissing. Sutter moves to her neck. Suddenly her hands stop moving and her body freezes. Sutter is confused.
What’s wrong?
Nothing. Just go ahead.
What do you mean, ‘just go ahead’?
Just do it. She lies perfectly still with her eyes closed.
I can’t... I’m not gonna just do it. What’s wrong with you? Sutter pulls away.
Are you thinking about Marcus? (she says nothing) Are you in love with him?
I don’t want to talk about him right now.
It’s just a yes or no thing. I’m not asking for a whole essay.
I don’t know... Maybe. (starts to cry) I'm, like, really confused right now.
What about us? This afternoon?
That's what got me so confused. Today has been... great.
But?
We always have fun. I mean, I don’t have fun with anyone like I do with you.
I agree --
But you can’t go around having fun all the time. Sometimes you have to be serious.
I am serious. I’m 100 percent serious. 50.  51.
About what?
About... not being serious. Enjoying things. Living in the moment.
I want more than just... “moments.” I want --
What?
A future. Sutter looks away. Starts to get dressed.
Are you mad?
I’m not mad. Whatever. You and I... friends. That’s terrific. Music up: a girl singing a contemporary folk song on acoustic guitar. CUT TO:

On Sutter’s utterly distraught face, we PULL BACK TO REVEAL he is at a birthday party, where all the kids are drinking pop and watching a pig-tailed GIRL play a song about Jesus on the guitar. He looks at Ricky who sits on the couch holding hands with Beth. They actually seem to be enjoying this. Sutter can’t take it anymore. Gets up and walks out.
Sutter walks down the stairs, wanders through the atrium.
Yo, Carmine! Sutter turns. It’s SHAWNIE BROWN (18, brunette, funky glasses, hip), on her way inside.
Ay Carmine, how you doin’?
I’m doin’ bravissimo, Carmine. Whatchoo doin?  52.
Just tryin’ to put some distance between me and dem stiffs upstairs at dat lame- ass party.
Ay-oh, I was just goin’ to that. No good?
Fuggettaboudit.
No, you fuggettaboudit.
Aaaay, you're breakin’ my balls. They both burst out laughing and hug.
So, really, the party’s lame?
Whatever you do Shawnie, do not go in there.
Shit. There’s, like, nothing else going on tonight.
(holding up his flask) There’s always something going on when I’m around.
A couple of old arcade games in the corner and a beat up ping pong table. They talk while playing ping pong.
Why didn’t you tell me that before I started dating him?
Would it have made a difference?
Probably not... Point game. (she serves) What about you?
What about me?
What’s up with you and Cassidy?  53.
Cassidy who?
(not buying it) Uh-huh.
The past is past, Shawnie Brown. You know me. I live in the now. She smashes a shot past Sutter.
Woo! Three games in a row, sucker.
Ping pong’s not my game.
Clearly.
(eyes a hot tub in the next room) Now that’s what I need. Sutter races to it, Shawnie follows. He feels the water.
You're not really going in there, are you?
Of course I am.
Bullshit. Sutter steps into the hot tub, fully dressed. He eases himself down into the tub.
You're crazy.
Yeah but that’s why you like me so much. So, Miss Queen of Ping Pong, your move...

You can never outdo me, Sutter. Shawnie follows him in, her white t-shirt clinging to her body, showing all. Sutter’s mouth drops and Shawnee smiles at him, knowing she’s won. For a beat they sit there together. And then, almost without thinking, Sutter kisses her.  54. It works -- for about a second before Shawnie starts giggling. Then it’s a full-blown laugh. Sutter can’t help but to laugh too. It’s contagious.
You know what, Sutter? You’re my favorite ex-boyfriend of all time. I’m sure going to miss you next year.
Why, where you going?
College. (beat) Aren't you?
Haven’t really thought about it.
Yeah, right. (beat) Wait, you’re serious? Sutter shrugs. Shawnie splashes him in disbelief.
You’re not going to college?
What for?
Sutter!
What?
It’s fucking college!

My Dad never went to college and now he’s, like, the number two real estate developer in Cook County. Who needs it? I have everything I need right here. A job. A car... A naked girl in a hot tub. Shawnie laughs. Sutter smiles at her.
Look at us. This moment right here. You're gonna remember this, aren’t you? It’s beautiful. You think beauty’s in some classroom? A text book? It’s not. It's here. It’s all around us.  55.
You're drunk.
Yeah but I’m not wrong. Shawnie thinks about it. Not completely wrong anyway.
Ay, you're breakin’ my balls here.

You're breakin’ my balls! They engage in a friendly splash fight as we TRACK AWAY. CuT TO: INT SUTTER’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Sutter comes in and sits at his computer. Again opens the college application window. The essay is now totally blank. He looks at the question. Quick glance to the pennant on the wall. Sutter takes a swig from the flask. Says out loud:
Fuck this. And turns off the computer.
Crowded with kids heading in all directions. And then there’s Sutter. He strolls down the hall until he spots Aimee at a distance. Her back is turned. Sutter quickly turns down another hallway.
Sutter is walking to his Lancer when:
Just who do you think you are? It's Krystal Krittenbrink, and she doesn’t look happy.
The King of Mexico?
Don’t think you’re going to joke your way out of this, Sutter. Aimee told me about your little party out by the lake.
And?  56.
And now you’re avoiding her.
I’m not avoiding anyone.
Really? Have you seen her since the party? Have you even called?
How bout you get off my back?
Ha, I knew Aimee got that from you. She said the same thing.
Did she? Good for her.
No, it’s not good for her. Aimee’s isn’t like you, Sutter. She’s a sweet girl. She doesn’t need you causing problems in her life.
(walking away) The only problem Aimee has is you bossing her around like she’s your personal assistant.
(yelling after him) You shouldn’t treat her this way.

(not stopping) Whatever buzzkill. INT SUTTER’S CAR - LATER Sutter drives around. Takes a drink from the Big Gulp. We can tell he’s thinking about what Krystal said. Rolls his eyes and makes a U-Turn. EXT AIMEE’S HOUSE - DUSK Sutter knocks. It takes a few moments for the door to open. It’s Shane. Before Sutter can say anything Shane turns his head.
Aimee! Your boyfriend’s back!
What? Oh, um, tell him to hold on a second, I’ll be right there.  57.
(cunning off) You tell him!
(to no one) Bye Shane. Sutter waits in the doorway. Drinks. After a few moments Aimee appears. She’s wearing what looks like a new shirt and her hair is all staticky from a quick brushing.
I didn’t know you were coming over today.
Yeah, no, I wasn’t, but uh... I was driving around and I thought, ‘I don’t care how busy I am. I want to see how Aimee’s doing.’ (off her smile) So... how you doing?
Good.
Good. Great. Listen, my sister is having a dinner for her swanky friends and I’m being forced to show --
You have a sister? I didn’t know that.
Yeah, well, we’re not really close. Anyway, would you wanna come with me?
Um... ok! When is it?
Ten minutes.
Oh. Uh... Sure! I’ll go get my coat.

Let’s leave the coat. INT HOLLY’S DINING ROOM - LATER ANGLE on HOLLY, Sutter’s sister, (25, heavily made up, dyed blonde hair, fake breasts and dressed to show them, jewelry glistening everywhere).  58.
»--and I said “could I get you boys anything else?” And he said, tell ‘em what you said honey. Holly’s husband JOE (early 40s, confident without cause) sits to her right.

I leaned back in my chair, puffed out my chest and I said... “You could give me your number gorgeous?” The PARTY GUESTS (mostly OLDER MEN and their YOUNGER SECOND WIVES) like this. Sutter, at the other end of the long table, makes the “vomit” face to Aimee. She laughs.
I had no idea he was a big fancy lawyer but I gave it to him anyway. And I’m sure glad I did!

Hasn't worked a day in her life since. Joe squeezes her leg. Holly pecks her husband on the lips. Aimee rolls her eyes at this. Signals for another top-off from the flask which Sutter provides out of view from the others.
Isn't that a great story?
Wow. You guys sure are a breath of fresh air.
Thank you Sutter.
It’s rare to see such happy couples nowadays. Seems like everyone’s divorced.
That’s not true.
Isn't it? My parents, (to Aimee) your parents, most of my friend’s parents --
Kid’s got a point.
Thank you Joe.  59.
Mine didn’t.
(confused) They didn’t? But I thought... Aimee shakes her head no.
See Sutter. Not everything is doomed.
My Dad died. That sucks the air out of the room.
I’m so sorry.
Not your fault. Aimee takes a drink. The guests shuffle in their seats.
Oh honey, what happened?
He was a great guy. He just... he had a... problem. Painkillers, mostly. No one really knows what to say.
He tried to stop a bunch of times, but... One day my sister came home and he was just lying there. She had to close his eyes.
Jesus. She takes another sip of her drink but this time doesn’t flinch.
(to Sutter) Anyway, I don’t agree with you. About marriage. Mine’s gonna totally work.
Oh yeah?
I’ve thought it all out. We’re going to live on a horse ranch, my husband and I. I’ll work for NASA. And my husband... (MORE )
Sutter is 60.

he'll do something completely different. And we'll offset each other. Like we’ll have some things in common but we’ll also have all these other dimensions that we bring to the relationship. And that’s how I know it’ll work. taken aback. Really impressed with her now.
(dismissive) Sounds like a dream.
(cight back at him) It’s good to have dreams. Don’t you think? Aimee looks at Sutter, smiles. Sutter, still stunned, smiles back. Raises his glass.
To dreams.
Where kids hang out cause there’s nowhere to go. Away from the party, Sutter and Aimee share a drink sitting on the roof of his car.
Did you mean what you said at the party?
Uh... which... thing --?
When you asked me to the Prom?
(beat) Well of course I remember that. Are you kidding? I wouldn’t forget something like that. There’s an awkward pause.
Do you still want to go? I mean, if you don’t, I'll understand.
What are you talking about? I totally want to go. I wouldn’t have asked you if I didn’t.
Really?  61.
Sure. Can’t wait. She looks at him and smiles. He smiles back. Starting to really like how happy he makes this girl.

(shutting off radio) Come here. They start to kiss. Sutter then stops. Takes off her glasses. Sets them on the hood. Kissing resumes. This lasts a few seconds before someone whistles at them from the water tower. Aimee and Sutter laugh.
Come on. I’ll take you home.
In the hallway, Aimee kisses Sutter goodbye. Holds on to his arm for as long as she can as they part. Sutter goes one way, she goes the other. Ricky joins Sutter with a disapproving look.
It’s under control. (Ricky shakes his head) Hey, did it ever cross your mind that I might actually be attracted to her?
That’s cause you haven’t really looked at her. I’m telling you. You have to talk to her a while before you can really see her. Ricky’s expression doesn’t change.
What am I doing that’s so wrong? Really? Worst case scenario, I’m giving her some much needed boyfriend experience.
That's worst case scenario?
Totally. (Ricky still shakes his head) You and I both know, another month tops before she’s done with me and moves on.
And what if she doesn’t?  62.
Well then that would be a first, wouldn’t it? Fair point. Jason Doyle walks over.
Hey Sutter, Marcus was looking for you.
Marcus? What for?

I‘ll let him tell you that. Jason walks away, smiling maliciously. Sutter and Ricky look at one another, knowing that can’t be good. INT LEWIS'S FINE MEN’S CLOTHING STORE - DAY Sutter is shadowboxing while talking to Bob at the men’s shop.
»--and he’s like yay big and I’m like yay big... so that’s bad. Plus, he’s fast. And his reach has got to be way out --
Sutter, what are you doing? You’re not a fighter.
Tell me about it!
So why’s he want to fight you?
I don’t know. He must think I’m still after Cassidy.
Is he right? Sutter stops boxing (clearly winded). Takes a drink from his Big Gulp.
No. I mean -- we talk, a little. Online mostly. (off his look) Hey, I’m the victim here. She chose him. (beat) Just cause I want to keep in touch with my ex doesn’t make me a bad guy. Does it?  63.

You're not a bad guy, Sutter. You just don’t have a real good grasp of the idea of consequences. LATER. Sutter turns off the lights. Goes outside, locking the door behind him. Big Gulp in hand. As he walks to his car:
We need to talk. Oh shit, it’s Marcus. Here we go.
Ok sure. Long as it’s quick --
What’s up with you and Cassidy?
Nothing’s up. Why, what have you heard? Marcus just stares Sutter down. Intimidating.
Look, man, I don’t want any trouble.
Tell me the truth. Marcus gets right up in Sutter’s face. Sutter knows if this gets physical, he’s not gonna win.
We're just friends. Honestly. She’s moved on. I’ve moved on...
You've moved on?
(not convincingly) I have.
Everyone knows you’d drop Aimee Finecky in a second if Cass would go back to you.

Everyone knows that? Well guess what... everyone’s wrong. (beat) Look, Marcus, trust me, ok. We hang out sometimes, we have fun, but I promise you, nothing’s going on between Cass and me.  64. Marcus continues to stare Sutter down. A beat. And then it’s Marcus who breaks the stare first. He looks down at his feet. Sutter realizes something -- he isn’t angry, he’s distressed.
(beat) Can I ask you something?
Oh...k.
Why can’t it be me she has fun with?
(beat; not expecting that) What?

I’m not like you, Sutter. I don’t know how to make her laugh and stuff. I want to, I just... I don’t know what to do. Can you help me? The direction of this conversation has thrown Sutter for a loop. Sutter is
Dude... you’re Marcus West. Star athlete. Class President. What’s that charity you started?
The Hope Brigade.
The Hope Brigade, for fuck’s sake. You're the man, Marcus! You don’t need my help.
The way she talks about you... it’s not the same, man. I want her to like me like that. And she doesn’t. I know she doesn’t. stunned to see Marcus so distraught and vulnerable. This is too weird.

Look, Marcus, you don’t want to be like me. Trust me. I make jokes and stuff but you... you get shit done. You’re gonna change the world. You guys are perfect together. Marcus’s mood is slowly improving. Sutter is on a roll.  65.
You just need to loosen up a bit. You're too tense.
Maybe.
All that charity work you do. Volunteering. It’s nice but, I mean come on, you’re young. Not everything has to be serious all the time. See a movie. Maybe have a beer once in a while.
That’s not for me, man.
I'm just saying... relax. Enjoy yourself, you know? Live in the now. Marcus sighs, taking it all in. What Sutter’s saying makes sense.
Thank you for talking to me like this, Sutter. I appreciate it. I really do.
Well sure --
You’re a good man. Sutter nods, feeling pretty good about the whole thing. Marcus walks back to his car.
Hey Sutter! (Sutter turns) They’re wrong about you.
What’s that?

You're not the joke everyone thinks. Sutter flinches, as if he just received the punch he was expecting all along. Marcus leaves and we remain on Sutter, thinking about that. CUT TO: INT AIMEE’S LIVING ROOM - LATER Sutter and Aimee sitting close together on her couch, watching TV.  66.
What do you think of the movie?
I’ve seen it before.
Oh. We can watch something else.
No I like it. Used to watch it with my Dad all the time. He loved this stuff.
Really? My kind of guy.
You would have liked him a lot. He’s the one who turned me onto music and manga and stuff. He was cool. Sutter puts his arms around her. Aimee likes the feeling.
What about you?
Hmm?
Do you miss your Dad?
Nah it’s cool.
He’s not flying back soon?
What?
You said he was an... airline pilot.
Um... yeah, exactly.
So... why can’t he fly to come see you?
Why are we talking about this?
It's important. If my Dad was alive --
I'm trying to watch the movie.  67.
I’m just saying... you should see him, before it’s too late. Sutter says nothing.
Maybe you can ask your mom --
(jumping up) Goddamit Aimee! Will you shut up already? Jesus Christ. Aimee’s face flushes red and she shrinks away. This is the first time Sutter’s gotten mad at her and it stings.
I’m sorry.
(cvealizing he snapped) No, I’m sorry. You just... kept going on and on.
(looking away) I know. I don’t know what’s wrong with me.

(sitting back down) Nothing’s wrong with you. I’m just... a little touchy about my Dad, ok. Come here. I’m sorry I yelled. Sutter hugs her tight. He then lifts her chin to look at him. Then he kisses her. The mouth. The forehead. The eyelids. Kissing the tears away. It grows in intensity. INT AIMEE’S BEDROOM - MOMENTS LATER And now they’re on the bed, kissing, fondling.

Can we take off our clothes? There’s no stopping it now. Sutter lifts off Aimee’s shirt. Aimee takes off her own bra. Sutter then takes his shirt off. Aimee helps him with his pants. It’s awkward but there’s a real romance to it. Sutter sees Aimee in a new light. And he’s amazed at what he sees.
Nudity looks awesome on you.  68. They get under the covers together. Feeling each other's bodies. Aimee stops first. Reaching over to the night stand. She pulls out a condom.
Just to be safe. Sutter is surprised. Girl’s got all the bases covered. Aimee helps him put the condom on. And then pulls him over towards her so he can be on top.
I like you so much.
You're spectacular. You really are.
I’m so glad I met you.

I'm glad I met you too. Slowly, tenderly, they begin to have sex. Sutter looks down at Aimee’s face. Her eyes are closed. It’s very different from sex with Cassidy but in a way it’s better. More intimate. More connected. Sutter is entranced. - LATER. They lie in bed together. Post-coital.
You're incredible.
Nah. It’s easy to seem that way on your first time. (Aimee looks away) It was your first time, wasn’t it...? Aimee? Her silence says maybe it wasn’t.
I thought you said you never had a boyfriend. Aimee sits up, pulls her knees to her chest. Chin down, looking very distraught.
I don’t want you to hate me.
Hate you? I won’t hate you. You’re un- hatable.  69.
It’s just something that happened... I was 14. I didn’t know anything about boys.
Ok.
Randy’s son Troy was sleeping over.
Randy? Your Step-father Randy?
(nods) We all went to sleep and then I heard this knock on my door. Troy said he couldn’t sleep and would I mind if he came in, talked for a while.
Of course he did.
He climbed in my bed. Got under the covers. And started... saying all this stuff to me...
What kind of stuff?
You know. How warm I feel. How much he likes my mouth and my hair.
Smooth talker, this Troy.
No one ever spoke to me like that. It felt... I don’t know... special. So I just... let him do it. (beat) I should have known better.
How could you? You were 14.
I still should have known no 20 year old would actually like me --
20? Are you fucking kidding me?  70.
And the worst part is... when we... finished... he couldn’t look at me. Drove away in the morning. I’ve never seen him since.
Oh man! That dude is king of the creeps. If I ever see that guy -- I can’t believe your mom stayed with Randy after that.
I never told her.
You never... How could you not --
I’ve never told anyone that. Until now. They both lie there quietly. Aimee puts her head on his chest. Sutter sits there thinking. Then he hears her lose it.
Don’t cry.
You must think I’m awful.

I don’t think you’re awful. Why would you say that? (beat) I‘ll tell you a secret. (beat) My Dad’s not a pilot... I’m not sure what he is. Or where. I just said that because... I don’t know... I don’t know anything about him. He’s been gone half my life and I... I guess I just miss him.
Doesn’t anyone know where he is?
Just my mom. She refuses to tell me.
That’s terrible! She can’t keep him from you. He’s your father. Sutter looks away. Uncomfortable.
(beat) I’‘ll make you a deal. I’ll stand up to my Mom, if you stand up to yours.  71. Sutter looks at her. Aimee puts out her hand to shake.
What do you say? Deal? Sutter hesitates. Then he just smiles, touches her face. Instead of answering he says:
You're spectacular. And then they lay together. She strokes his hair as he looks at the ceiling.
Sutter waits in line to take his Yearbook picture. Cassidy approaches.
(fixes his hair) There you go.
Thanks.
Haven’t seen you in a while.
How's Marcus?
Good. How’s Aimee?
Couldn’t be better. A beat.
I gotta say, Sutter, I’m impressed. (off his look) I admire you... for going out with her.
“Admire?” That’s an odd word.
No I mean... you don’t usually go for those kinds of girls.
What can I say? I’m evolving.  72.
(coy) . Maybe you’ll amount to something after all.
I'm already something. I’m a miraculous marvel is what I am. She laughs. It’s comfortable between them.
Anyway... I'd better get back. Good seeing you. She turns to go. He watches.
Sutter is walking to class when he hears:
Sutter! Mr. Aster calls to him from inside his classroom.
Would you come in here please? Sutter exhales and turns left into Aster’s class.
Have a seat. Aster hands him a homework assignment. A big red D+.
(upbeat) It’s not an F.
I thought you were getting help.
I am.
Well now you need a C on the final or you fail my class.
I’ll try harder.
No you won't. That takes Sutter by surprise.  73.
I don’t get you, Sutter. You’re a smart kid. Thoughtful. Do you even want to graduate?
(beat; thinks about it) I’m not sure.
Excuse me?

I'm being honest with you. The truth is, I really don’t know. I like it here. I like being young. Everybody’s rushing me to grow up, move on -- why? What’s so great about it? Aster doesn’t know what to say.

Are you happy, Mr. Aster? Aster is silent. Sutter shrugs. Takes his paper and goes. INT AIMEE’S HOUSE - PROM NIGHT Tuxedo-clad Sutter stands in the kitchen with Aimee’s MOM and Randy. Aimee’s Mom has the camera out and is readying to take some prom pictures. AIMEE’S MOM Randy, get in there with Sutter. The two men pose for the picture. As odd a couple as you're likely to see. Sutter pretends to be comfortable. Finally Aimee comes down. She’s wearing the lipstick again, her dress is a pale yellow that doesn’t quite match her skin tone, and she’s done her hair up in a leaning tower of Pisa style do. An awkward girl trying too hard to look elegant. Sutter doesn’t care about that.
You look fabuloso.

Thanks. So do you. They do the boutonniere/ corsage exchange. Mom takes a few more. Randy’s already turned his attention to the game on TV. They say their goodbyes and they’re off. INT SUTTER’S CAR - LATER Sutter’s car has been washed for the occasion. They sit together.  74.
Sorry I didn’t get you a limo.
That’s ok.
Let me make it up to you. He pulls out a small wrapped gift from the glove compartment.
You didn’t have to --
I wanted to. Aimee tears the wrapping paper off of the box. Opens it. A flask.
Just like mine. And you’ll notice it’s already full too.
I love it!
Shall we (toast)? (vaising his flask) To you, Aimee Finecky. They toast. Aimee leans in to kiss him. When it’s over:
Ok then. Let’s go to prom!

Sutter and Aimee arrive at the venue which, when not hosting a high school prom, is a horse track. Tonight it’s lit up with white Xmas lights and made to look very romantic. Aimee adjusts the straps on her ill-fitting dress. Sneaks a drink from her flask. Sutter takes Aimee’s arm and they walk inside.

The prom is already in full swing and it’s very much like you'd expect -- DJ, punch bowl, padded chairs, white tablecloths. Through Sutter’s eyes, the whole place sparkles. People greet him as they always do when he shows up to a party. High-fives etc. Sutter and Aimee choose a half- empty table to sit at. Sutter pulls out a chair for her like a gentleman. They sit and take it all in.  75.
You want some punch?
Sure.

Back in a jiff. Sutter heads over to the punch bowl. Pours two glasses. Nods to Ricky who is sitting with Beth. And then he sees Cassidy, on the dance floor with Marcus. Her dress is amazing, showing off her voluptuous body in the perfect way. Sutter takes a moment to watch but then shakes it off, heads back to his table, hands Aimee the punch which she immediately spikes.
Cheers. Sutter wants to give Aimee his full attention but his eyes can’t help returning to Cassidy. Eventually:
She’s a good dancer.
Hmm?
Cassidy.
Oh, yeah, I hadn’t noticed. Aimee doesn’t push the issue. Sutter downs another drink. And so does Aimee. The song ends and Cassidy sees Sutter at the table. She walks over with Marcus.
Why aren’t you two dancing?
You know I hate this kind of music.
Who cares? It’s the prom. Aimee, c’mon!
I’m not much of a dancer.
That's why you got me. I can teach you some of my moves.
(taking a big sip) I’m good right here. You two go ahead.  76. Sutter and Cassidy share a look.
You sure?
It’s fine. Aimee takes out her flask and re-spikes the drink. Sutter hesitates for a beat, sizing up whether Aimee is telling the truth.
If you change your mind... Aimee turns back around. Sutter shrugs. He and Cassidy head to the dance floor. Once they’re dancing:
She looks nice.
She does.
What’s with the flask? You’re not turning her into a lush are you?
You wanna dance or lecture me about Aimee?

I wanna dance. Sutter spins her. They’re getting more comfortable now. Sutter accidentally bumps into another guy who looks pissed. Sutter apologizes. Song over, Sutter bows to Cassidy who curtsies back. Then they part ways. He watches her walk over to Marcus before turning to walk back to Aimee. Sutter kisses her cheek as he sits down next to her. Aimee smiles. Seems like she means it. Then again, might be the alcohol talking. Sutter takes her hand and holds it at the table. He looks around the room. Sees Ricky and Beth having fun. Sees Shawnie twirling on the dance floor with her date. Everything he sees makes him happy.

Amazing, isn’t it, Aim? All these kids. Dressed up, dancing, singing, falling in love... This is our night! St. Patrick’s Day for the young. (beat) Do you realize -- right now, this moment, this is as young as we’re ever gonna be. (MORE )

This is it. The spectacular now. (beat) God, I love these people. The song ends and a new one begins, slower, more romantic. Sutter grabs Aimee and gestures to the floor. This time she doesn’t resist. They dance. her head on Sutter’s shoulder.
I’m sorry I can’t dance like Cassidy.
dance She puts You dance like Aimee. And that’s perfect. We stay with them a few beats. A nice moment. - LATER. Sutter and Aimee walk out of the main room and out onto the grounds.
We're gonna miss the King and Queen.
Fuck that. We’re all Kings and Queens tonight.
(starting to slur) That’s right! I’m the Queen.
And I’m your King.
I need to sit down. They take their seat on a bench. The stars are out tonight. It’s beautiful. Neither says a word for a second. Aimee starts to but stops herself.
What is it?
You have any more?
Uh, yeah, here.
(drinks) I’ve been thinking... about the summer. My sister said she could get me a job at a book store.
In St. Louis?  78.
Uh-huh.
A book store’s perfect for you.
I know! And it’ll help pay for college.
Have you talked to your mom yet?
No but I will.
That’s excellent. I can’t think of anything better.
I can. (beat) Come with me.... Sutter doesn’t know what to say to that.

I’ve looked into it. You can take classes at the junior College. We’ll both get jobs downtown. In our free time we can go to Forest Park or hang out by the river. Have you ever seen the Mississippi? I’ve only seen pictures but it looks amazing.
(beat) Wow. That’s... that’s some plan. You've really done your homework.

Yeah. And best of all my sister says there’s tons of vacancies in her building cause of the economy and stuff. They’re not expensive at all. We could move at the end of June. You and me. Sutter remains dazed, silent.
Sutter... what do you think? Looking at Aimee, Sutter knows there’s only two possibilities. Break her heart right now -- or just go with it.

I think... that’s a terrific idea. Best I’ve ever heard.  79. Aimee embraces him. They kiss. We can tell what she can’t: Sutter is not convinced about any of this. - LATER. Sutter and Aimee walk back into the room. Aimee is ecstatic. Sutter looks pained now. The joy of the buzz completely sucked out of him. The prom itself seems to be equally pallid. The room has thinned out. The glitter is crumbling. The lame decorations are half on the ground. There’s no sign of Sutter’s friends. Depression threatening, Sutter makes his move.
This is ridiculous. Hops up on the riser and grabs the mic from the DJ.
Can I have everybody’s attention? The music stops. There’s a little feedback from the mic.
Come on people, let’s pick this party up. This is our night. Some people yell out “woo Sutter” etc. Aimee is by this point too drunk to shout. Others are clearly less enthusiastic.

How bout I add a little class to the evening? (clears his throat) A 1 anda 2 and 1 2 3.. (sings) “You're nobody till somebody loves you. You're nobody till somebody cares.” Sing it with me. Sutter doesn’t remember the next line. The crowd starts to turn on him.
Da da da... shit. Um... “Head keeps spinning, go to sleep grinning, if this is just the beginning, my life will be beautiful!”
Sit down!
You sit down. Dickhead.
Go back to rehab!  80. Other kids start shouting too. Mr. Aster runs over to put a stop to it.
Alright Mr. Keely, that’s enough.
I’m just warming up.
I said that’s enough.
This is our night, Mr. Asterhole, not yours. Some people cheer the dig at the teacher but not everyone.
That’s it, your prom’s over.

Fine. We’ll take this party elsewhere. Sutter drops the mic on the ground. Hops off the riser. Stumbles a little on the way down but covers it up well enough. He still thinks he’s under control but the stares from his classmates say otherwise. Sutter pays them no mind. Cassidy runs up to him.
You have to take Aimee home.
Cass where you been?
In the bathroom with your girlfriend. She passed out on the floor!
Ouch. Was it my singing?
This is not a joke Sutter.
Ok, ok, I’ll take care of her.
I don’t think you know how.
Hey, this is none of your business, Cass.  81.
It’s not about me. And it’s not about us. It’s about -
Stop! Aimee comes out, walking at a bit of a tilt, covered in vomit, angry.
Get away from him. You’re not his boyfriend.
I was just trying to get him to --
I know what you were trying to do. You were practically... dancefucking!
Whoa.
Aimee --

Stay away from him, you fat bitch. At which point Aimee winds up and slaps Cassidy across the face, hard. But in the process, she loses her balance and falls onto the punch bowl table, crashing it to the floor. Cassidy looks at Sutter as if to say “look what you've done to her.” Sutter receives the look, brushes it off, and runs to Aimee’s aid.
Can you sit up? Are you cut? Come on, let’s get you up in this chair. He lifts her up, gently.
I’m sorry. I’m so sorry.
Don't be sorry. It’s the prom, things happen at the prom.
I’m such a mess.

You’re beautiful. Let’s get out of here. Sutter helps Aimee to her feet. She takes one step and vomits again onto the floor.  82. Anyone still watching the scene (which is most people) groan at the sight. Sutter sees Cassidy still giving him that look, the same one he got a thousand times as her boyfriend.
She’s just not used to partying so hard.
Cassidy, I’m sorry...
It’s OK.
(starts crying) No, really...
Take her home, Sutter.
I will. Come on, baby, you'll be alright. Everything’s gonna be alright. And with Cass watching, as he helps her out of the room:
I love you, Sutter. I love you so much. And this is like a gunshot to Sutter. Of all the things to happen tonight, that one stings the most. BLACK.

head_text.subj: HOLD A FEW SECONDS AND THEN FADE IN

text: Sutter rings up a customer -- Jason Doyle.
Nice-looking suit.
Present from my pops. You should have seen him when I got into Dartmouth. Guy was in tears. Sutter doesn’t say anything.
You pick a college?
Yeah.  83.
Which one?
(beat)
Nice. Go Gators.
See ya around Jason. Once he’s gone, Bob appears in the doorway to the back room.
Sutter -- Bob gestures for Sutter to follow him into the back. Sutter does. Sits down in the desk across from him.

You've probably noticed we’re not too busy these days. And because of that... well, I can only keep one clerk. (Sutter nods, waits for it) You know I like you, Sutter. More importantly, the customers like you. So I think you should be the one I keep.
That’s excellent, Bob. Thank you! You won’t regret it.

Hold on a sec. (beat) I’ve given this some hard thought, and the only way I can let you stay is if you promise me, 100 percent, that you’ll never come in here loaded again. Sutter is taken aback by this. He never thought Bob was on to him.
I’m serious. Not even a light buzz. And if you do, one time, I’m gonna have to let you go. Do you understand?
I do.
Can you promise me, Sutter?  84. Bob looks Sutter in the eye. Sutter holds his gaze for a beat, then laughs to himself.
You've got me there, don’t you, Bob? You know I can’t promise that. Bob looks at Sutter, disappointed, hoping he’1ll reconsider. Knows he won’t.
I appreciate your honesty.
Of course, Bob. I’m always up front with you. Sutter, proud of himself, rises to shake Bob’s hand.
It's been a pleasure working for you Sir. Bob stares at him a beat. Then shakes his hand.
I guess... if I was your dad, here’s where I’d give you a lecture or something... ‘bout what you’re doing to yourself.
You know what, Bob... If you were my Dad, you wouldn’t have to.
Sutter leaves, loosening his tie on the way out. Feeling pretty good until:
Can we talk to you for a minute? Cassidy stands on the sidewalk.
Who’s we? She points to a parked car. Marcus and Ricky are inside. INT MARCUS’ CAR - CONTINUOUS Sutter sits next to Ricky in the back. Marcus and Cassidy are in the front. They all look at him.
